structural_elements: States organize around stable attractors; recall is basin descent
fidelity_notes: Keth's cognitive basins → memory palace structure. Five families may reflect basin multiplicity.

structural_elements: Similar states reinforce each other; resonance enables recall
fidelity_notes: Keth's resonance → 'absolute correspondence' principle. Similar patterns link in memory.

structural_elements: Vigilance parameters control memory stability
fidelity_notes: Keth's tradeoff → schools disagree on balance. One school favors retention another flexibility.

structural_elements: Exponential decay; reactivation preserves ghosts
fidelity_notes: Moll's ghosts → memories that fade without practice. Reactivation → rehearsal protocols.

structural_elements: Bodies 'read' forms; memory accesses pre-existing patterns
fidelity_notes: Pol's reading → placing memories in paintings. Visual art as memory library interface.

structural_elements: Following gradients to remembered states
fidelity_notes: Voss's pathfinding → finding correct memory through associative gradient. Destination paradox applies.

structural_elements: Triggered/Autonomous/Modular/Emergent memory levels
fidelity_notes: Anster's mind levels → levels of mnemonic skill. Triggered (rote) to Emergent (creative recall).

structural_elements: I-C-∫ formula for cognitive coherence
fidelity_notes: Anster's integration → techniques for connecting disparate memories. Coordination across memory domains.

structural_elements: Same substrate computes differently for different observers
fidelity_notes: Creel's polycomputing → each mnemonist develops unique system. Same training different methods.

structural_elements: Neighbor relationships form memory constellations
fidelity_notes: Tross's constellations → memory palace structure. Items cluster by relationship not just sequence.

structural_elements: Positive/negative edges create memorable tension
fidelity_notes: Tross's tension → memorable oppositions. Strong memories from contrasting associations.

structural_elements: Six domains of cognitive breakdown
fidelity_notes: Vorn's taxonomy → diagnosing mnemonic problems. Why certain techniques fail for certain people.

structural_elements: How potential memories become actual recall
fidelity_notes: Vells's ingression → the moment of successful recall. Potential memory becoming actual experience.

structural_elements: Temporal depth and agential range of memory
fidelity_notes: Strand's horizons → recognizing what can't be remembered. Designing systems within cognitive limits.

structural_elements: Prime-number behavioral cycles (2 3 5 7 11)
fidelity_notes: Brent's creature rhythms → rhythmic rehearsal patterns. Prime cycles may optimize retention.

structural_elements: Parts negotiate with wholes through trust
fidelity_notes: Mord's federations → Five Family structure. Collective memory across family units.

structural_elements: Trust determines information flow between parts
fidelity_notes: Mord's trust → why methods work better in family lineages. Trust enables memory transmission.

structural_elements: Memory valid only at moment of recall
fidelity_notes: Guild principle → memories must be remade. Continuous practice prevents decay.

structural_elements: Six principles for mapping unstable regions
fidelity_notes: Guild mapping → memorizing difficult/changing material. Dens instability → memory instability.

structural_elements: 2/3/5/7/11 patterns in cognition
fidelity_notes: Prime patterns → optimal rehearsal intervals. Spacing based on prime cycles may enhance retention.

structural_elements: Subjects who know they're being observed
fidelity_notes: Crost's reflexivity → knowing how your memory works. Self-observation improves technique.

structural_elements: Unknown core principles
fidelity_notes: Gap: W1 source for The Mnemonist's original method unclear. Dens may have obscured origins.
